Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will connect two areas of modern research in mathematics:the first is topology, the second is graph theory and network flows. Topology is the qualitative study of space and its connectedness. Its importance was recognized at the turn of the last century by the French mathematician Poincare, during his investigation of the laws of motion that govern the movement of a three-body system such as the Earth, Moon and Sun moving according to Newton's laws. In the past twenty years, topology has seen applications in questions such as the knotting of proteins and DNA, and in modern theories of high-energy physics. The topology of three-dimensional spaces, as opposed to those of higher dimension, is of particular subtlety. Graph theory also has a long history. It is the mathematical theory of networks and their connections, and sees application in many aspects of computer science, algorithms and optimization. By viewing networks as embedded in three-dimensional space, this project aims to use techniques from topology to study questions in graph theory. The topological techniques will be drawn from many sources, but particularly from gauge theory, a field having its origins in fundamental physics. The project will deepen our understanding of topology and its interaction with other areas of mathematics and science. At the same time, the project will train graduate students and disseminate results to researchers in the area.

The project activity will be in the following specific areas. In collaboration with T. S. Mrowka, the PI will develop a new instanton homology for spatial trivalent graphs. This will be defined using a gauge theory related to representations of the fundamental group of the graph's complement in the group of rotations, SO(3). This SO(3) instanton homology will be a finite-dimensional vector space over the field of two elements. A proof will be completed, that the dimension of the SO(3) instanton homology is always non-zero, for any bridgeless, spatial trivalent graph. The PI will investigate the dimension of the SO(3) instanton homology for general planar trivalent graphs. It is expected that the dimension is always related to the number of three-edge-colorings of the graph. If the previous two goals are achieved, it will follow that every bridgeless, planar trivalent graph admits at least one three-edge-coloring, a major result in the field. Instanton homology theories for trivalent graphs defined using larger gauge groups such as SU(N) will be investigated as part of this project. The SU(3) case is expected to play a role in understanding the SO(3) instanton homology. Relations will be explored, between SU(N) instanton homology and categorifications of quantum invariants, such as Khovanov-Rozansky homology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The four-color theorem is a famous result in mathematics whose history stretches back to the 19th century. It states that for any map composed of regions separated by borders in the plane, it is possible to color the regions of the map with only four colors in such a way no two regions with a common border have the same color. A proof was finally given in the 1970s, by Appel and Haken, with an argument that depended on a large amount of computer verification.

Another direction of mathematical research with 19th century origins is the study of knots: closed knotted loops in three-space, whose investigation forms part of the mathematical area of topology in three dimensions. New tools for the study of knots and topology were developed by Andras Floer in the 1980s, using differential equations originating in mathematical physics. This "Floer homology" has been an active area of research in the intervening decades, and has led to a deeper understanding of many questions in knot theory.

The purpose of this project was to bring together these two previously unrelated areas of research. By focusing on the network formed by the boundaries in a map, it is possible to reformulate the four-color theorem as a result about planar networks, or graphs. Enlarging one's viewpoint, one can consider such graphs or networks as embedded in three-dimensional space, perhaps in a knotted manner. The tools of three-dimensional topology, and in particular Floer homology, then become useful tools with potential application to questions such as map-coloring.

The main scientific outcome of this work was the development of a new variant of Floer homology, directly applicable to the knotted networks in three-space that arise in the map-coloring problem. A key result was the proof of the non-triviality of this Floer homology, with an argument drawing on several classical techniques. In addition, a precise conjecture was formulated, based on the evidence of several classes of examples, concerning the size of the Floer homology of a knotted network. The truth of this conjecture, if it can be verified, would lead to a new proof of the four-color theorem, independent of the computer-assisted techniques that have previously been used. In developing these tools, the technical foundations have been laid for future work on the applications of Floer homology.

Beyond the scientific outcomes, the broader impacts of the project have occured through the dissemination of these results and through the training and career development of graduate students and researchers. This work has been presented through lectures (including a presentation to a general audience at the Radcliffe Institute for Adanced Study), through technical seminars (some of which have been made available online), through a class aimed at graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, and through journal publications. Two graduate students worked specifically on questions related to this project and have since moved on to tenure-track positions.
